While I've expressed some concern about rock music and probably think Christians should avoid it, on this topic some of the lyrics of the rock band "Black Sabbath" come to mind (from their song ["War Pigs"](https://www.metrolyrics.com/war-pigs-lyrics-black-sabbath.html)):

> Time will tell on their power minds
> Making war just for fun
> Treating people just like pawns in chess
> Wait 'til their judgement day comes

> Now in darkness world stops turning
> Ashes where the bodies burning
> No more war pigs have the power
> Hand of God has struck the hour
> Day of judgement, God is calling
> On their knees the war pig's crawling
> Begging mercy for their sins
> Satan laughing spreads his wings

This sounds kind of like a rock adaptation, consciously or unconsciously of the older traditional ["Dies Irae" song:](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dies_irae) 

> Oh, what fear man's bosom rendeth,
> When from heaven the Judge descendeth,
> On whose sentence all dependeth.

Culturally, it seems like there was an awareness in the past that politicians (for example) who are in power and abuse their power (and commit sin) would be judged for doing so on Judgment Day. Reminding them that God is all-powerful and that there is no appeal against the verdict decided on Judgment Day, can act as a powerful psychological tool to correct abuses in the world. 

If more politicians were reminded that God can punish them also in this world and even cut their lives short in this life, or could cast them in to hell for ever in the next life, perhaps they would repent or turn away from the sins they commit (even out of a simple fear for self-preservation, if they had not developed a love of doing what is good). 

> There is a way which seemeth just to a man: but the ends thereof lead to death. Proverbs 14:12

We saw how that [Argentinian pro-abortion leader](https://www.liveaction.org/news/leader-argentina-dies-legally-taking-abortion-drug/) tragically died while having an abortion. She thought she was safe, but was not; God allowed her to be delivered over to sin, and then the sin brought about her death. And it is fearful to think of what God's judgment will be over her soul.

So, spreading this reminder of the fear of God's judgment might help to correct politicians, or to inspire us to reform our own lives which is important for improving our world.

> Thou hypocrite, cast out first the beam in thy own eye, and then shalt thou see to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye. Matthew 7:5

Just as Jordan Peterson encourages people to "clean their room" (or work to improve the problems in their own lives) before expecting to see the world reformed, we might look at the things that need improvement in our own lives before expecting to see some kind of political change out in the world. 

And for politicians or ourselves, if we are willing to be sorry from the heart and willing to actually change for the better and to try to make up for bad things we have done, the Bible speaks in multiple verses about God's willingness to forgive.

> If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just, to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all iniquity. 1 John 1:9

What do you think we could do to spread this awareness of the coming of Judgment Day, or what else on these topics should we talk about?

Prayer For The Government [(Written By Catholic Archbishop Carroll in 1791 for the inauguration of President George Washington.)](https://www.archbalt.org/prayer-for-our-government-by-archbishop-john-carroll/)

> We pray Thee, O Almighty and Eternal God, who through Jesus Christ hast revealed Thy glory to all nations, to preserve the works of Thy mercy; that Thy Church, being spread through the whole world, may continue with unchanging faith in the confession of Thy Name.
We pray Thee O God of might, wisdom, and justice, Through whom authority is rightly administered, laws are enacted, and judgment decreed, assist, with Thy Holy Spirit of counsel and fortitude the President of these United States, that his administration may be conducted in righteousness, and be eminently useful to Thy people over whom he presides; by encouraging due respect for virtue and religion; by a faithful execution of the laws in justice and mercy; and by restraining vice and immorality. Let the light of Thy divine wisdom direct the deliberations of Congress, and shine forth in all the proceedings and laws framed for our rule and government, so that they may tend to the preservation of peace, the promotion of national happiness, the increase of industry, sobriety, and useful knowledge; and may perpetuate to us the blessing of equal liberty.
We pray for his excellency, the governor of this state, for the members of the assembly, for all judges, magistrates, and other officers who are appointed to guard our political welfare, that they may be enabled, by Thy powerful protection, to discharge the duties of their respective stations with honesty and ability.
We recommend likewise, to Thy unbounded mercy, all our brethren and fellow citizens throughout the United States, that they may be blessed in the knowledge and sanctified in the observance of Thy most holy law; that they may be preserved in union, and in that peace which the world cannot give; and after enjoying the blessings of this life, be admitted to those which are eternal.

(There is more to the prayer on the link, but this is how it appears in another text I have)

Let the light of Thy divine wisdom direct the deliberations of Congress, and shine forth in all the proceedings and laws framed for our rule and government, so that they may tend to the preservation of peace, the promotion of national happiness, the increase of industry, sobriety, and useful knowledge; and may perpetuate to us the blessing of equal liberty.

We recommend likewise, to Thy unbounded mercy, all our brethren and fellow citizens throughout the United States, that they may be blessed in the knowledge and sanctified in the observance of Thy most holy law; that they may be preserved in union, and in that peace which the world cannot give; and after enjoying the blessings of this life, be admitted to those which are eternal.

> Hand of God has struck the hour
> Day of judgement, God is calling

> Begging mercy for their sins

> Oh, what fear man's bosom rendeth,
> When from heaven the Judge descendeth,
> On whose sentence all dependeth.

If more politicians were reminded that God can punish them also in this world and even cut their lives short in this life, or could cast them in to hell for ever in the next life, perhaps they would repent or turn away from the sins they commit (even out of a simple fear for self-preservation, if they had not developed a love of doing what is good).

> If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just, to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all iniquity. 1 John 1:9

While I've expressed some concern about rock music and probably think Christians should avoid it, on this topic some of the lyrics of the rock band "Black Sabbath" come to mind (from their song ["War Pigs"](https://www.metrolyrics.com/war-pigs-lyrics-black-sabbath.html)):

> Time will tell on their power minds
> Making war just for fun
> Treating people just like pawns in chess
> Wait 'til their judgement day comes

> Now in darkness world stops turning
> Ashes where the bodies burning
> No more war pigs have the power
> Hand of God has struck the hour
> Day of judgement, God is calling
> On their knees the war pig's crawling
> Begging mercy for their sins
> Satan laughing spreads his wings

This sounds kind of like a rock adaptation, consciously or unconsciously of the older traditional ["Dies Irae" song:](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dies_irae) 

> Oh, what fear man's bosom rendeth,
> When from heaven the Judge descendeth,
> On whose sentence all dependeth.

Culturally, it seems like there was an awareness in the past that politicians (for example) who are in power and abuse their power (and commit sin) would be judged for doing so on Judgment Day. Reminding them that God is all-powerful and that there is no appeal against the verdict decided on Judgment Day, can act as a powerful psychological tool to correct abuses in the world. 

If more politicians were reminded that God can punish them also in this world and even cut their lives short in this life, or could cast them in to hell for ever in the next life, perhaps they would repent or turn away from the sins they commit (even out of a simple fear for self-preservation, if they had not developed a love of doing what is good). 

> There is a way which seemeth just to a man: but the ends thereof lead to death. Proverbs 14:12

We saw how that [Argentinian pro-abortion leader](https://www.liveaction.org/news/leader-argentina-dies-legally-taking-abortion-drug/) tragically died while having an abortion. She thought she was safe, but was not; God allowed her to be delivered over to sin, and then the sin brought about her death. And it is fearful to think of what God's judgment will be over her soul.

So, spreading this reminder of the fear of God's judgment might help to correct politicians, or to inspire us to reform our own lives which is important for improving our world.

> Thou hypocrite, cast out first the beam in thy own eye, and then shalt thou see to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye. Matthew 7:5

Just as Jordan Peterson encourages people to "clean their room" (or work to improve the problems in their own lives) before expecting to see the world reformed, we might look at the things that need improvement in our own lives before expecting to see some kind of political change out in the world. 

And for politicians or ourselves, if we are willing to be sorry from the heart and willing to actually change for the better and to try to make up for bad things we have done, the Bible speaks in multiple verses about God's willingness to forgive.

> If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just, to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all iniquity. 1 John 1:9

What do you think we could do to spread this awareness of the coming of Judgment Day, or what else on these topics should we talk about?

Addendum: typo fixed, "pro-life" to "pro-abortion"

> While I think it might work for some people

It won't work for anyone. It might actually make some people put up an insincere show and that's even worse, because then they can't be seen and be reached.

> By this I'm not supporting things that church made in the past, but saying that hell doesn't exist and judgment day is not definitive, is just wrong.

There is no record of hell in the first several centuries of Christianity. There were annihilationists and universalists, which is also in line with Judaism. That some sketchy denominations believe in these doesn't make them guilty by association. The closest thing to hell among early Christians was some universalists believing in a temporary purgatory-like place of punishment, and more similar to underworld myths than a place where people burn 24/7. Even if hell was mentioned, there is even less indication of an "end of grace" that everyone seems to think is going to happen, as if Jesus's sacrifice wasn't good enough. Actually the gospels mention Jesus evangelizing to the dead before his resurrection, which would be pointless if it was too late for them. And don't start telling me about Tribulation, because the whole point of that is to try and convince people to change their minds.

> I have no idea about original greek, but there are numerous places where hell is described in parables by Jesus.

See that's kinda the problem, the translations are in many places dishonest and swayed by the beliefs of the translators. When you see "hell" in your bible, know that it's actually either the grave, Hades, or Gehenna. Only the devil is said to be tortured "forever" in the "lake of fire" and the authenticity of Revelation is itself questionable.

The grave: Figurative place where dead people are, or the state of being dead, and in the old testament everyone goes there. You probably already know. It's pretty safe to rule this out.

Hades: Greek place of the dead, used to translate the former term. Usually it is used for the same purpose, not as much for the Greek concept of it with the underworld.

Gehenna: Hell is right here on Earth, apparently. This is a valley where the Pharisees burned people who they ostracized as "sinners". It was regarded as cursed for that reason. The new testament sometimes alludes to it as either a place of death and complete destruction or a tragic fate of not being allowed to enter the kingdom, depending on the interpretation. Not where God mercilessly burns people forever.

While I've expressed some concern about rock music and probably think Christians should avoid it, on this topic some of the lyrics of the rock band "Black Sabbath" come to mind (from their song ["War Pigs"](https://www.metrolyrics.com/war-pigs-lyrics-black-sabbath.html)):

> Time will tell on their power minds
> Making war just for fun
> Treating people just like pawns in chess
> Wait 'til their judgement day comes

> Now in darkness world stops turning
> Ashes where the bodies burning
> No more war pigs have the power
> Hand of God has struck the hour
> Day of judgement, God is calling
> On their knees the war pig's crawling
> Begging mercy for their sins
> Satan laughing spreads his wings

This sounds kind of like a rock adaptation, consciously or unconsciously of the older traditional ["Dies Irae" song:](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dies_irae) 

> Oh, what fear man's bosom rendeth,
> When from heaven the Judge descendeth,
> On whose sentence all dependeth.

Culturally, it seems like there was an awareness in the past that politicians (for example) who are in power and abuse their power (and commit sin) would be judged for doing so on Judgment Day. Reminding them that God is all-powerful and that there is no appeal against the verdict decided on Judgment Day, can act as a powerful psychological tool to correct abuses in the world. 

If more politicians were reminded that God can punish them also in this world and even cut their lives short in this life, or could cast them in to hell for ever in the next life, perhaps they would repent or turn away from the sins they commit (even out of a simple fear for self-preservation, if they had not developed a love of doing what is good). 

> There is a way which seemeth just to a man: but the ends thereof lead to death. Proverbs 14:12

We saw how that [Argentinian pro-abortion leader](https://www.liveaction.org/news/leader-argentina-dies-legally-taking-abortion-drug/) tragically died while having an abortion. She thought she was safe, but was not; God allowed her to be delivered over to sin, and then the sin brought about her death. And it is fearful to think of what God's judgment will be over her soul.

So, spreading this reminder of the fear of God's judgment might help to correct politicians, or to inspire us to reform our own lives which is important for improving our world.

> Thou hypocrite, cast out first the beam in thy own eye, and then shalt thou see to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye. Matthew 7:5

Just as Jordan Peterson encourages people to "clean their room" (or work to improve the problems in their own lives) before expecting to see the world reformed, we might look at the things that need improvement in our own lives before expecting to see some kind of political change out in the world. 

And for politicians or ourselves, if we are willing to be sorry from the heart and willing to actually change for the better and to try to make up for bad things we have done, the Bible speaks in multiple verses about God's willingness to forgive.

> If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just, to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all iniquity. 1 John 1:9

What do you think we could do to spread this awareness of the coming of Judgment Day, or what else on these topics should we talk about?

Addendum: typo fixed, "pro-life" to "pro-abortion"

really?

> > Then shall he answer them, saying, Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye did it not to one of the least of these, ye did it not to me. And these shall go away into everlasting punishment: but the righteous into life eternal.

"The outer darkness," probably better translated as "the darkness outside," doesn't describe hell at all, it describes a state of despair and exile.

> Oh, what fear man's bosom rendeth,
> When from heaven the Judge descendeth,
> On whose sentence all dependeth.

If more politicians were reminded that God can punish them also in this world and even cut their lives short in this life, or could cast them in to hell for ever in the next life, perhaps they would repent or turn away from the sins they commit (even out of a simple fear for self-preservation, if they had not developed a love of doing what is good). 

> There is a way which seemeth just to a man: but the ends thereof lead to death. Proverbs 14:12

We saw how that [Argentinian pro-abortion leader](https://www.liveaction.org/news/leader-argentina-dies-legally-taking-abortion-drug/) tragically died while having an abortion. So, spreading this reminder of the fear of God's judgment might help to correct politicians, or to inspire us to reform our own lives which is important for improving our world.

> Thou hypocrite, cast out first the beam in thy own eye, and then shalt thou see to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye. Matthew 7:5

Just as Jordan Peterson encourages people to "clean their room" (or work to improve the problems in their own lives) before expecting to see the world reformed, we might look at the things that need improvement in our own lives before expecting to see some kind of political change out in the world. 

And for politicians or ourselves, if we are willing to be sorry from the heart and willing to actually change for the better and to try to make up for bad things we have done, the Bible speaks in multiple verses about God's willingness to forgive.

> If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just, to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all iniquity. 1 John 1:9

What do you think we could do to spread this awareness of the coming of Judgment Day, or what else on these topics should we talk about?

> Making war just for fun

> Now in darkness world stops turning
> Ashes where the bodies burning
> No more war pigs have the power
> Hand of God has struck the hour
> Day of judgement, God is calling
> On their knees the war pig's crawling
> Begging mercy for their sins
> Satan laughing spreads his wings

This sounds kind of like a rock adaptation, consciously or unconsciously of the older traditional ["Dies Irae" song:](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dies_irae) 

> Oh, what fear man's bosom rendeth,
> When from heaven the Judge descendeth,
> On whose sentence all dependeth.

Culturally, it seems like there was an awareness in the past that politicians (for example) who are in power and abuse their power (and commit sin) would be judged for doing so on Judgment Day. Reminding them that God is all-powerful and that there is no appeal against the verdict decided on Judgment Day, can act as a powerful psychological tool to correct abuses in the world. 

If more politicians were reminded that God can punish them also in this world and even cut their lives short in this life, or could cast them in to hell for ever in the next life, perhaps they would repent or turn away from the sins they commit (even out of a simple fear for self-preservation, if they had not developed a love of doing what is good). 

> There is a way which seemeth just to a man: but the ends thereof lead to death. Proverbs 14:12

We saw how that [Argentinian pro-abortion leader](https://www.liveaction.org/news/leader-argentina-dies-legally-taking-abortion-drug/) tragically died while having an abortion. She thought she was safe, but was not; God allowed her to be delivered over to sin, and then the sin brought about her death. And it is fearful to think of what God's judgment will be over her soul.

So, spreading this reminder of the fear of God's judgment might help to correct politicians, or to inspire us to reform our own lives which is important for improving our world.

> Thou hypocrite, cast out first the beam in thy own eye, and then shalt thou see to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye. Matthew 7:5

Just as Jordan Peterson encourages people to "clean their room" (or work to improve the problems in their own lives) before expecting to see the world reformed, we might look at the things that need improvement in our own lives before expecting to see some kind of political change out in the world. 

And for politicians or ourselves, if we are willing to be sorry from the heart and willing to actually change for the better and to try to make up for bad things we have done, the Bible speaks in multiple verses about God's willingness to forgive.

> If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just, to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all iniquity. 1 John 1:9

What do you think we could do to spread this awareness of the coming of Judgment Day, or what else on these topics should we talk about?
